title: R44325
content: The level of pay for congressional staff is determined by Senate committees, with job titles, pay rates, and resources set by the chair and ranking Member. There is interest in congressional pay data for various reasons, but publicly available sources do not provide aggregated data. The data in this report is based on official Senate reports published semiannually. The Secretary of the Senate publishes a report semiannually on Senate committee staff compensation, with data available since FY2001. The report provides pay data for 13 staff position titles used in Senate committees, excluding titles filled by only one staff member or used by six or fewer panels. Annual pay data is collected for each position title. Annual pay data for 13 staff positions in Senate committees is collected, excluding titles used by only one staff member or by six or fewer panels. Data includes overtime, bonuses, and other payments in addition to base salary. Staff must hold the same job title in the same committee for the entire fiscal year to be included. Pay data for House committee staff is available in a separate report. Pay Levels for Selected Positions in House Committees, 2001-2014 are available in CRS Report R44323. Data may not fully represent all positions held by Senate committee staff due to title assignments. Two main categories of positions were identified, with pay information likely to be highly representative for positions held by one staff member per committee. The pay data collected for Senate committee staff positions may not fully represent all positions due to title assignments. There are two main categories of positions, with pay information likely to be highly representative for positions held by one staff member per committee. The data does not provide insight into factors such as education, work experience, or job duties that may affect compensation levels. Congressional employing authorities have wide discretion in setting terms of employment, leading to potential differences in duties and pay levels for similarly titled staff. The Senate Handbook acknowledges that individuals with the same job title in Congress may have vastly different duties, leading to variations in pay levels. Tables in the report provide data on Senate pay practices, maximum payable rates for committee staff, cumulative percentage changes in median pay for different positions, and tabular pay data for each Senate committee staff position. The data may not fully represent all positions due to title assignments, and factors like education and job duties that may affect compensation levels are not accounted for. Congressional employing authorities have discretion in setting terms of employment, resulting in potential differences in duties and pay levels for similarly titled staff. Between FY2011 and FY2015, median pay for Senate committee staff positions saw changes ranging from a 16.93% increase for professional staff members to a -16.48% decrease for staff assistants. Two positions had pay increases while seven saw declines. Comparatively, Members of Congress saw a -5.10% change in pay during the same period.
